On Boana punctata species group: Molecular phylogenetics, phylogeography, species delimitation, and implications to taxonomy and evolutionary history
Project
Herein we aim to discuss the phylogenetic relationships within the species. As well as investigate the intraspecific diversity patterns with an emphasis on the widespread Boana punctata-atlantica species complex.
View
Diversity, systematic, biogeography and conservation of Peruvian Andean water frogs.
Project
The rising of the Andes and Pleistocene climate fluctuation were the principal force that modeled biological diversity in the Andes. Tropical Andes is one of the most important hotspots of biodiversity and ecosystems. However, aquatic diversity in the Andes has received less attention than terrestrial diversity from the research and conservation community. The aquatics environments of tropical Andes and Altiplano are the habitats of one of the most diverse native groups of frogs from South-America, the genus Telmatobius Wiegmann, 1834. Approximately 50% of their diversity is in Peru. However, today several species are under risk extinction by multiple factors, this phenomenon is taking place while we are still far from having a complete understanding of the species richness, distribution, biogeography, and phylogenetic relationships of members of the genus Telmatobius. We attempt, using a multidisciplinary and collaborative approach, to contribute knowledge about this anurans, through a) Study the phylogenetic systematics of Peruvian species of Telmatobius, b) study cryptic diversity in complex Telmatobius species, under integrative taxonomy approach c) Biogeography, distribution and characterization their habitats, d) Threats, the effect of emergent diseases in Telmatobius populations and conservation implications. For this, we have been using different approaches: phylogenetic studies, ecology, sdm, disease ecology, and conservation biology.
View
The phylogeny of bothropoid pitvipers (Bothrops, Bothrocophias)
Project
Bothropoids are a highly diverse group of pitvipers whose phylogeny is not yet sufficiently clear given the uncertain, unclear or conflicting position of many species. Our goal is to assess the contribution of new data and an increased taxon sampling for the outgroup on clarifying the phylogeny of bothropoids. New data includes new morphological and molecular characters, additional data of poorly known species, data of species described recently, and data of putative new species.
